mc_pro_critic_reviews.summary: Plenty of credit is due to Barbara Curry’s deranged script, set in a suburban fantasyland of doofus bullies, junior proms, and middle-class sex fears; it probably isn’t meant to be a Verhoeven satire, but it sure moves like one.
Predictable and foolishly unsuspecting characters react in ways that make you want to shake them. But there's an undeniable sense of silly fun in this erotic thriller.
The movie's not built for belief. It's built for dumb, shivery, sexed-up pleasure, and it delivers, albeit somewhat modestly.
Boy's premise reeks of stalker-movie mothballs, and it's too timid to fully dive into the high camp it hints at. Instead, this cookie just crumbles.
It will also make them laugh. Intentionally or not, director Rob Cohen (“Alex Cross”) has put together the most hilarious camp classic since “White House Down” (2013).
It’s unashamedly of the B-movie variety — a quick and easy time-killer.
For those seeking guilty laughs and shameless camp, The Boy Next Door is the exact right kind of bad movie. It’s full of unintentional laughs, and transcendently unselfconscious.
The film goes for broke with such a careening lack of inhibition, it definitely ends up in the fun zone.
Props to director Rob Cohen for making a gender-flipped 'Fatal Attraction’. But The Boy Next Door really should be a lot juicier.
Mr. Cohen, no stranger to delivering pulp product, employs visual clichés as if they were flash cards; no exposed thigh or made-you-jump reveal goes unexploited.
It's no surprise The Boy Next Door is junk. What is disappointing is that it's not fun junk. It doesn't even merit a good hate-watching, because the whole thing is so meh.
It offers January moviegoers some guilty-pleasure thrills and laughs, while falling way short of its potential on both the dramatic and the camp fronts.

The Boy Next Door has its share of so-bad-they’re-good moments – and details, and chunks of dialogue – but not nearly enough. Mostly, they’re just bad. And it had such potential too, starting with the casting.

I wish The Boy Next Door were a different, zingier sort of mediocrity, but whenever it threatens to go the full Zalman King "Two Moon Junction" route, it pulls back and behaves itself and settles for a grindingly predictable series of escalations.
The film is so gleefully ridiculous that you start to suspect the filmmakers were in on the joke and forgot to tell the actors.

Lopez is a gorgeous woman with the same mousy voice she came into the movies with 20 years ago. She’s all about the makeup, the hair, the clothes. She plays the part like someone imitating a TV teacher, from her classroom posture to her delivery.
The Boy Next Door plays best as unintentional comedy.
Breathless, uninspired January junk that feels like the iffiest bits of a Lifetime movie and late-night cable schlock slapped together. (And not erotically.)
While Lopez carries off the overdone damsel-in-distress schtick somewhat credibly, Guzman fails to step up to the trickier role of her seducer and stalker.

Neither good nor bad, nor campy nor scary enough to be in any way memorable, The Boy Next Door is a lot like our own neighbors, just there. You could make the effort to sneak a peek, but it probably wouldn’t be worth your while.
The film’s initial formulaic competence gives way to outright preposterousness rather quickly, hinging on idiot-plot character motivations.
The Boy Next Door aspires to be a cautionary tale, but it unspools like an infomercial - with a shockingly gory ending.

B-movie director Rob Cohen (The Fast and the Furious) hasn’t got a clue what to do with so much preposterous pulp fiction, so he wafts between sexy potboiler and psychological thriller with an uneasy lack of grace that brings out the worst in everybody.
It's badly directed, poorly edited, and features some of the most unconvincing acting this side of a soup commercial.

It's a thriller, if the term can be applied to an inept, perfunctory movie with more laughs than thrills — and it only has a couple laughs. Let's call it an attempted thriller and an inadvertent comedy.
Everyone in The Boy Next Door has to behave like an idiot at least once or twice, just so the movie can keep going. It’s an act of mercy when it finally grinds to a halt.

Why Lopez decided to do this inept, cliche-infested film is anyone’s guess. She may be an actress of limited range, but her work includes solid movies like “Selena” and “Out of Sight.” Unfortunately, Lopez’s resume now includes this stinker. And we’re all the dumber for it.
Unintended laughs far, far outnumber intended thrills.

The sub-par acting, overdramatic cinematography and horribly predictable shock value of the film makes it all the more difficult to sit through without laughing at the ludicrous production or checking a cellphone to gauge how much torture one is expected to sit through before it finally ends.
It’s Fatal Attraction 101.

The camera regards Guzman's buttocks and Lopez's breasts with an evasion of visual pleasure that could be blamed on the actors' nudity clauses if the entirety of the film didn't resemble a Lifetime movie embarrassed to have found its way to theaters.
The entire movie feels like a warning for women of any age: if you act on your desires, you will be punished. And there seems to be no greater punishment than having to watch The Boy Next Door.

A limp psychosexual thriller that takes a promisingly trashy conceit... and does absolutely nothing with it, and saddles it with wooden performances, poor staging, and a complete lack of conviction. It reaches a nearly operatic level of ineptitude.

mc_user_reviews.text: The movie is somewhat of a joke but for the most part and interesting joke. Yes the acting is not great and it has some cheap thrills but it kept my attention all the way through. Not bad for what it is.

Not nearly as bad as the critics would lead you to believe.  J. Lo is solid in it, and the "boy next door" is actually not a bad actor.  The seduction and sex scenes are pretty hot, but it does ramp up to the crazy pretty quickly thereafter.  Won't spoil anything here, but I will say that the total lack of post-climax resolution left me and my audience a little wanting.  Certainly worth seeing if you're up for some classic stalker-type fare.

How stupid do these film makers think we are who the hell keeps giving Lopez acting jobs this woman can not act  and she is just way too old to act as Damsel in Distress. As about the scenario is is full with cliche and the ending was stupid and unsatisfying the movie was a total waste of time do not waste your money... Miss Lopez should go in retirement she is 45 years old enough with her trashy movies and her awful acting already !!
The Boy Next Door is a thriller without the thrills. Lopez's horrible performance and Ryan Guzman's lack of menace make for a film better left in the director's Closet Next Room.

Let me start of by saying Jennifer Lopez looks amazing in this movie. I loved the story line; not exactly happy with the ending but it did make some good Hollywood sense. All I can say is that trust me you will be pleased with this movie. After all those years, Jennifer Lopez still makes for a good female lead and great movies. She's really underrated actress.

I read unfounded criticism, even and especially from critical specialists of film, and I'm laughing. It is above all the prejudices they have, rather than an intellectual reflection in several stages. I have to say that the films with small budgets are not the worst, they rely on the actors and the characters they have interpreted.

I went in expecting the worst based on reviews but this is the most FUN i've had with a film in a long time tbh! :) Yes, it's rather predictable and the script is nothing to write home about but the acting is solid and the whole movie is just pure fun! Lopez and Guzman do a very good job with what they were given... and at the end of day it's just a very sexy fun thriller best watched with friends! I highly recommend it! ;)

The movie is not so bad as the critics say. It's made for guilty pleasure and has those silly moments that get stuck in your head for days. It's clearly one of those silly movies you watch once in a while just to have some fun and there's a lot of fun. JLo's acting is great on it.
I loved this movie I think can see it a couple more times again...It is really intense and you want to get to see what will happens next that at the end I was like is that it? lol

I was surprised when I saw critic's reaction on this movie. It really isn't bad. Actually it is a fun movie to watch, and has many funny moments that made everyone in the room take some good laugh. Definitely going it see it again tomorrow.
It's a really entertaining movie. Buy popcorn, take your friends with you and HAVE FUN. Not to mention that  JLo is super hot and her acting is on point.

This movie proved to be the intense yet entertaining thriller the trailer showcased, the movie also provided some comical moments, Ryan Guzman was a fitting choice for the Obsessed young guy infatuated by Clare Peterson (played by Jennifer Lopez). Go see the Boy Next Door!

this movie is ms lopez at her best and its very entertaining me and a few friends made it a fun night out it was great and noah was  After all those years, Jennifer Lopez still makes for a good female lead and great movies. She's really underrated actress

What is it with "people from the street" feigning intellectual? First, it was Mark Wahlberg in "Gambler," now it's Jennifer Lopez as a high school classics teacher. The titular boy (Ryan Guzman), who's physically hot and mentally unstable, develops a possessive obsession with her. This plot is so overworked that I was sometimes calling the shots as they happened. To make matters worse, there are glaring lapses of logic. Still, director Rob Cohen manages to keep it interesting, although entirely forgettable.

Just came back from seeing it and the theater was sold-out. The movie is really entertaining and definitely a popcorn movie to see with friends and have fun. I think it's a great step away from the romcoms she has done so many of. I like her as an actress more than singer, but she is good in everything. Can't wait for the movie with Viola Davis, called Lila & Eve ;)

When a woman befriends the new boy living next door she finds her world turned upside down when he turns out to be a stalker who has watched Fatal Attraction a few too many times. A film that looks as though it was made in the 80's, it is hard to see how this made it onto cinema screens. Its outcome is a foregone conclusion after the first 10 minutes, you spend the duration of the movie hoping it is going to confound expectations - and it doesn't.

I wasn't even turned on by watching "The Boy Next Door" because there's not enough scares for me to snack on. I would rather watch "The Cell" (easily one of J. Lo's signature thriller) than seeing sexpot Lopez and that guy from "Jem And The Holograms." I really love the sex scenes featured in this movie, but nothing new. I don't know why Fast & The Furious director Rob Cohan directed this turd. It seems as though Hollywood is trying to be obsessed describing as the next "Fatal Attraction." It turns out that formula didn't work either. And that's why Jennifer Lopez' performance is the absolute worst. Just avoid it.

Let's face it, you must here to see Jennifer Lopez running from some psycho in her night gown or equally revealing outfit because the poster indicated such prospect. If that's the case, there isn't much aside from flirtation and edited illusion of what may come mainly on the first act, and if you're here for scare or horror, bless you. The Boy Next Door is virtually the same type of movie since Mark Whalberg's Fear almost two decades ago, only worse and without any depth or innovation.

There is no doubt that parts of this film will thrill. Whether that's the story crafted by Barbara Curry or the direction from Rob Cohen. It's not awards-caliber filmmaking, but it's not all bad here. And don't underestimate Jennifer Lopez.

There is no redeeming qualities in this movie it is complete garbage.  All the performances are terrible, the script is terrible, and the directing is terrible.  Easily the worst film I've seen all year.  F

Screenwriter Barbara Curry's screenplay debut, this isn't a good start for a movie that has dumb characters that do stupid outraging things so thing so that the film Could continue on the big screen. If there's one problem that has Director Rob Cohen has done with his films is having bad casting, really! letting Kristin Chenoweth play as the vice principal? and Jennifer Lopez (JLO) play a English /literature teacher also having a 27 year old Ryan Guzman play an almost  twenty year old psycho? this movie is all about a literature teacher who is divorced has problems with her cheating husband and has a kind  teenager Kevin. who meets Noah next door  then they have sex cause apparently their attractive? then all of a sudden is a psycho. he starts writing graffiti also  stalking her then it gets more out of hand. Rob Cohen does have well good shot action sequences in addition good suspense. But all the movie wants is making Jennifer Lopez  look good in a action/suspense movie. Grade B-

I saw the trailer for this before I saw Ouija a few months ago, and I said I would never watch it... guess that plan fell through. It wasn't completely horrible. The first 45 minutes were so unintentionally hilarious. I saw it with a couple friends, and we haven't laughed so hard during a movie in a while. The last 50 or so minutes is where the action picked up, and it got pretty intense for that. The acting is subpar, and the writing is atrocious, but it's an alright movie to waste 95 minutes on.
Comes across as made for cable soft core silliness. Whar was J. Lo thinking? Just a terrible piece of trash although it does look good. Give it a pass.

This movie is one of the worst January has to offer. However, this movie is so hilariously bad, it makes it watchable. Seriously watch this movie, you want regret it. Except for the fact that Jennifer Lopez doesn't get naked which would have made it more watchable.

Currently an entertaining and good movie overall...  I do not understand the critics and the atrocities that some alleged professionals are saying ... this movie is not intended as a masterpiece, and yet it is a good movie that fulfills exactly what it promises in the trailer. You can improve things of course (like all the things in this world), but  you will enjoy watching it and you will leave satisfied the cinema.
I loved this movie.  Jennifer Lopez is a doll and Ryan Guzman--wow, what a hunk.  Hope to see him in a romantic role playing a normal guy, if there is such a thing. :)
Great thriller!! Had me on my toes the entire time. J Lo is surprisingly a good actress.!! The ending was not that great but overall movie was awesome!
But why is Ryan Guzman wearing so many clothes? We were expecting a lot more illicit affair, and a lot less thriller plotline. And that copy of the Illiad? http://bit.ly/1Jqa64d
I have been looking forward for this movie, especially that I love Jennifer Lopez. I consider it a good psycho thriller movie, but not that excellent.
